parts: Name this quarterback who was drafted second overall in the 1998 draft, behind Peyton Manning. He is often considered one of the biggest busts in NFL history.
While Leaf was drafted by the Chargers, Peyton Manning was drafted by this team. Later, Manning would lead this team to a victory in Super Bowl XLI.
This person was hired as president and GM of the Colts in 1998 before leaving in 2011. He drafted Manning first overall after discovering that he could throw further in practices than Ryan Leaf.
Name this current head coach of the Green Bay Packers. Earlier, he worked as the offensive coordinator for both the Rams and Titans.

Matt LaFleur worked with Sean McVay and Kyle Shanahan, two coordinators known for deploying this offense, made famous by Bill Walsh. This offense places a smaller emphasis on running the ball and typically employs lots of short passes.
The Packers's success with the West Coast offense is due in no small part to this person, their offensive coordinator.
This Bengals superfan went to his first game in 1968, and has only missed 2 games in the next 51 seasons. In 2018, NFL Network did an 8-minute profile on this superfan.
The Bengals' most successful head coach was arguably this coach of the Bengals from 2003 to 2018. Despite leading the Bengals to 7 playoff appearances, he never won a playoff game with the team.
The Bengals logo is based on a tiger—it features black and this other color. The official team colors of the Bengals are black, white and this color.

answers: New York Jets [prompt on New York]
Dallas Cowboys [accept either underlined part] and Detroit Lions [accept either underlined part; accept in any order; both teams required]
parts: Name this team that plays its games at Metlife Stadium and typically wears green. There is some debate as to whether or not head coach Robert Selah will start Sam Darnold as this team's quarterback next season.

This player was the quarterback for the New York Jets during the butt fumble. In his first two seasons, this quarterback would lead the Jets to playoff success, but he regressed after the 2010 season.
The "butt fumble" occured on Thanksgiving Day, a holiday which these two teams always play on. Name both.

answers: running out of the end zone [accept any answer that describes running out of the end zone or running into the back of the end zone; accept word forms or obvious equivalents]
parts: Name this person often considered to be the one of the worst general managers in history. Besides that role, this person was the team president and CEO of the Lions during the winless 2008 season.
Because the Lions were winless in 2008, they achieved this record, the first team in NFL history to do so. This win-loss record would later be achieved by the Browns in 2017.
In one infamous play from the 2008 season, quarterback Dan Orlovsky did this action against the Vikings when he was at his own 1 yard line, which resulted in a safety. A description is fine.

answers: pass interference [or PI; accept offensive pass interference or defensive pass interference or OPI or DPI; do not accept or prompt on partial]
illegal leverage [do not accept or prompt on partial]
parts: Name this penalty that occurs when a defender grabs onto, holds, or otherwise interferes with a receiver's ability to catch the ball. If the penalty is against the defense and more than 10 yards from the line of scrimmage, then the ball is placed at the spot of the foul, unless it occurred in the end zone.
This penalty occurs when a defensive lineman touches an offensive lineman before the ball is snapped. It should not be confused with offsides or a neutral zone infraction.

This penalty occurs if a defensive player attempts to use their own teammates to gain extra momentum or height to block a field goal. The Patriots were called for this penalty in a 2013 game against the Jets, during which Bill Belichick pointed out that the Jets had earlier committed the same foul.
Name this team that plays in Georgia. It's not the Cardinals, but this team's logo features a red and black bird.
This player from South Korea is the current kicker for the Falcons. This kicker is known for his ability to successfully perform onside kicks.

In 2017, Younghoe Koo was on the Chargers, but he was waived after Week 4 after one blocked and one missed game-winning field goal. Koo was replaced by this kicker, a 10-year veteran at the time, who would end up playing for 6 NFL teams.

answers: Washington Football Team [accept either underlined part; accept WFT; accept Washington Redskins]
FedEx Corporation [accept FedExField; accept Federal Express]
parts: Name this team that won the NFC East in the 2020 season. This team's owner, Dan Synder, finally agreed to change its name after pressure from NFL teams following the George Floyd protests.

In the 2020 wild card round, this backup quarterback started for the Washington Football Team after Alex Smith was ruled out due to injury. He re-signed with the WFT with a 2 year, $8.75 million dollar contract.
The WFT only changed its name after external pressure, including threats of losing funding from this sponsor, who also names the stadium they play in.

answers: New England Patriots [accept either underline part; accept The Pats]
parts: Name this team that plays its games in Gillette Stadium in Foxborough, 22 miles southwest of Boston.

In 2009, the Patriots receiving corp consisted of players such as Randy Moss and this receiver. This player led the NFL in receptions in 2007, 2009, and 2011, and he also holds the Patriots record for most receiving yards in a single game at 217.

In 2007, despite Welker catching a record 11 receptions, the Patriots lost Super Bowl XLII after David Tyree made the infamous "helmet catch", and this Giants receiver caught the game-winning touchdown reception with 35 seconds left.

answers: NFLPA [or National Football League Players Association; or NFL Players Association]
parts: Name this labor union that represents the players of the NFL. It is affiliated with the larger AFL-CIO.
One of the most contentious issues during the lockout was about the "cap" on this quantity. More generally, it refers to how much money a player makes every year.
This person was the executive director of the NFLPA during the 2011 lockout, a position he still holds. He was elected unanimously to his position in March of 2009.
Name this longtime Steelers center. Ben Rothlesburger has called this player his "comfort blanket".

On November 14th, 2019, Maurkice Pouncey was involved in an altercation when this defensive end for the Browns ripped off Mason Rudolph's helmet after he allegedly said a racial slur. Afterwards, this Browns defensive end was suspended for the rest of the season.
The Browns are located in this state, which is also home to the Pro Football Hall of Fame in Canton.

answers: it ended in a tie [accept obvious equivalents]
parts: Name this head coach of the Eagles from 1999 to 2012, though he may be better known for being the current head coach of the Kansas City Chiefs.

Under Reid, the Eagles drafted this quarterback with the second overall pick in the 1999 draft. This player would later start as quarterback for the next 10 seasons with the Eagles, and he denies being sick during Super Bowl XXXIX.

In 2008, McNabb played a game against the Cincinnati Bengals, which had this unusual property, the first instance in 6 years. After that game against this team, McNabb claimed that he was not aware that games could have this property.

answers: Chicago Bears [accept either underlined part; accept Da Bears]
William Anthony Perry [accept "The Refrigerator" or "The Fridge"]
Walter Payton [accept Walter Payton Man of the Year Award]
parts: Name this team called the "Monsters of the Midway", located in Illinois. Mike Ditka coached this team for 11 years when it played games at Soldier Field.
One of the players Ditka coached was this 315 pound defensive lineman, who sometimes played fullback in goal line situations. He is the heaviest player to score a touchdown in Super Bowl history.

Ditka also described this player as the greatest football player he had ever seen, but even greater as a human being. This legendary Bears running back also names a "Man of the Year" award for players who do charitable work off the field.

Name this regular season game, where TV operators switched the broadcast to its namesake movie with approximately 1:30 left in the game. This game sparked outrage across the nation, convincing networks that they needed to broadcast every game to its conclusion.
The Heidi game was broadcast on this TV network, whose logo features a colorful peacock. Other shows on this network include Saturday Night Live.
The final score in the Heidi game, 43-32, was the only time that the score has been achieved in NFL history; thus, it is considered one of these scores. This term was popularized by Jon Bois.

answers: Kansas City Chiefs [accept either underlined part]
parts: Name this early rival league to the NFL. This league merged with the NFL in 1966, creating the league we know today.
This commissioner of the AFL was opposed to the idea of a merger, so owners from both leagues discussed the idea behind his back. He may be better known for owning the Oakland Raiders for 39 years.
This was the last team to win the AFL championship. The Green Bay Packers would go on to defeat this team in the first ever Super Bowl.

answers: extra point [or PAT; or point after touchdown; prompt on try or convert]
Jacksonville Jaguars [accept either underlined part; accept Jags]
parts: Name this 2003 play where the Saints, down 20-13, used three laterals to score a last minute touchdown. The game ended up not mattering, as the Saints wouldn't have made the playoffs even if they had won.
Despite being down 7 points, the Saints failed to win the game because kicker John Carney failed to make one of these kicks, which take place after touchdowns.
The River City Relay took place against this team, which was owned by Wayne Weaver at the time. Weaver then sold the team to Shahid Khan, who owns this team to this day.

answers: St. Louis Rams [accept either underlined part; prompt on Los Angeles or LA]
parts: The Chiefs lost that 2018 game by a score of 54-51 to this team, which was led by Jared Goff. In that game, Todd Gurley rushed 12 times for 55 yards for this team.

One of the reasons why the Rams won that game is because this linebacker returned an interception 25 yards for a touchdown. Earlier in the same game, this Rams linebacker recovered a fumble and returned it for a touchdown as well.
The Rams were also helped by this kicker, who made 2 field goals and 7 extra points. He would later go to the Cowboys, where he is their current starting kicker.
Name these events where teams select college players for their team. Players typically "declare" for this event, and in 2021, it will take place at the end of April.
In 1935, this co-owner of the Philadelphia Eagles proposed the draft. This person was also responsible for the first true merger between the NFL and the AAFC.
From 1946 to 1959, Bell held this highest position in the NFL. Pete Rozelle and Paul Tagliabue would succeed him as holders of this position.

answers: Super Bowl XXV [or 1991 Super Bowl; or 1990 Super Bowl]
parts: Name this Super Bowl, the only such game to have been decided by one point. The Buffalo Bills lost this game when Scott Norwood's 47 yard field goal sailed wide right. A description is fine.
In that game, defensive coordinator Bill Belicheck successfully contained this player's K-gun offense. This is the only Buffalo Bills quarterback to have his number retired by the team.
Jim Kelly and the Bills lost to the New York Giants, who play in this NFC division, named after the geographical region the Giants are in.

answers: dislocating his pinky finger [accept breaking his pinky finger; accept word forms; prompt on partial; prompt on any answer that contains hand]
parts: Name this starting quarterback for the Las Vegas Raiders as of 2021.

Description acceptable. In 2016, in a game against the Panthers, Carr received this type of injury on a bad snap, causing him to "scream in pain". Despite this, Carr was miraculously able to make a return in the 4th quarter.

This player, the backup for the Raiders from 2013 to 2016, took Carr's place in that game. He was the first walk-on quarterback to start at Penn State since 1949, and he would later have a brief stint as the 3rd string quarterback for the Texans.
